div.p: seven years ago I was in grad school
studying water I wanted to research tsos
but the data was not in order HTML
tables across a hundred pages the data
was crap lat long zat lacked the time
stamps overlapped adjust for a map and a
pop ups were blocked the page didn't do
jack so I quit the idea and studied
storm or modeling instead for almost
five years I didn't think of it again
till forest brought it up at 1871 one
night talking about Chicago data hidden
in plain sight here is discussing it as
we SAT around a table and there I am
feeling excited willing but unable I
come to hack met a few times said hello
but didn't find my jam so this group
were kindled my entrance and shown me
that I can I asked him with his
connections if he could get the source
I'd like to do some analysis but I
needed in a usable form he looked me up
you looked me down and said so you can
code just write a program to scrape the
page to find what you want to know
stackoverflow in Java code and I was
able to deliver after five years I had
finally a historic record of sewage in
the river so thank you hack night number
85 where I built that overflow tracker
and my mentality started to shift from
engineer to hacker to tell if a CSO was
currently happening Derek Forrest and
van santen started is their sewage in
chicago river comm joining forces with
them was the bomb money woman's fame and
fortune none of that came but we we
almost made something
afterwards I thought back to grad school
and the things I could have done I was a
reminded of a gif project on fecal
coliform I had built a visualization
from random samples down the coast but I
had wanted to report which beaches were
closed the most now with my super powers
of Wayne of web scraping writing scripts
I remembered the website I first saw at
hack night number 86 so yeah I got up
here every week and had some fun talking
about beaches and making duty puns a new
guy started at work one day as the
extended his hand he said hey you're the
pool guy I said yes I am direct beach
didn't have much purpose and again there
wasn't a dime so I schemed to build my
next water idea on my company's time at
what a 12-week sprint the mix of work in
hack night was kind of sorted I think we
did some really cool things but we're
only getting started a spatio-temporal
rain data set is missing from open
source I think we'll have it soon but

p.span: there is work to do of course with the

div.p: array of things raspberry PI's and
sensors on the portal our data points
are growing feeding fuel to our models
in the 21st century water starved world
the city is truly blessed but we're
wasteful including with a system they're
stressed our infrastructure is old and
inefficient we need some better ways
despite zorconian cuts the Great Lakes
restoration and the EPA I wanted to take
this moment to remind you that five
years is too much time to not quench
your curiosity and leave your questions
on the line this community is a resource
for you as you figure to fit in so
follow the data and build something
awesome before hack night turns 10
you
[Applause]
